file_metadata.title: An ability to respond begins with inner alignment: How phase synchronisation effects transitions to higher levels of agency
file_metadata.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>How do multiple active components at one level of organisation create agential wholes at higher levels of organisation? For example, in organismic development, how does the multi-scale autonomy of the organism arise from the interactions of the molecules, cells and tissues that an organism contains? And, in the major evolutionary transitions, how does a multicellular organism, for example, arise as an evolutionary unit from the selective interests of its unicellular ancestors? We utilise computational models as a way to think about this general question. We take a deliberately minimalistic notion of an agent: a competency to take one of two possible actions to minimise stress. Helping ourselves to this behaviour at the microscale, we focus on conditions where this same type of agency appears spontaneously at a higher level of organisation. We find that a simple process of positive feedback on the timing of individual responses, loosely analogous to the natural phase synchronisation of weakly coupled oscillators, causes such a transition in behaviour. The emergent collectives that arise become, quite suddenly, able to respond to their external stresses in the same (minimal) sense as the original microscale units. This effects a dramatic rescaling of the system behaviour, and a quantifiable increase in problem-solving competency, serving as a model of how higher-level agency emerges from a pool of lower-level agents or active matter. We discuss how this dynamical ‘waking-up’ of higher-level collectives, through the alignment of their internal dynamics, might relate to reproductive/cell-cycle synchronisation in evolutionary transitions and development.</jats:p>

chunks.text: How do multiple active components at one level of organization create agential wholes at higher levels?  We use computational models to explore this question, focusing on how agency emerges from simpler components.  We consider a minimal definition of agency: the ability to take actions to minimize stress.  Our models show that positive feedback on the timing of individual responses, similar to phase synchronization of oscillators, can lead to emergent collective agency.  These collectives suddenly become able to respond to external stresses, demonstrating a dramatic rescaling of system behavior and increased problem-solving competency.  We discuss how this relates to synchronization in evolutionary transitions and development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Simple agents coordinating their actions through phase synchronization can exhibit emergent collective agency and enhanced problem-solving.

chunks.text: The question of how multiple individuals transition from acting separately to working together as a single entity is explored across various levels of organization, from molecular biology to human society.  Examples include the development of an organism from its constituent cells and tissues, and the evolutionary transitions from unicellular to multicellular organisms.  Understanding how new levels of agency arise, both in developmental and evolutionary time, is a key challenge.
chunks.chunk_summary: The transition from individual to collective agency is a fundamental question in both development and evolution.

chunks.text: While reductionist explanations can be appealing, they often overlook the constraints and affordances imposed by higher-level organization.  This paper focuses on understanding how individuals co-create organizational conditions that promote cooperation, even when it seems to oppose their self-interest.  We shift the focus from defining agency categorically to understanding how competency at one level transitions to a higher level.  We consider the competency to take actions that optimize a quantity, such as minimizing stress, and explore how this competency can emerge at a collective level.
chunks.chunk_summary: Understanding how collective agency emerges requires considering the constraints and affordances of higher-level organization, rather than just individual actions.

chunks.text: This paper uses computational models as tools to explore the logical consequences of different scenarios and assumptions related to multi-scale competencies and transitions.  The focus is not on creating specific models of development or evolution, but rather on illustrating general principles.  The hypothesis explored is that transitions in agency can occur through adjustments in the timing of decisions.
chunks.chunk_summary: Computational models are used to explore the general principles of multi-scale competencies and transitions, focusing on the timing of decisions.

chunks.text: The driving conventions problem illustrates the conflict between individual and collective agency.  Drivers within a country easily reach a consensus on which side of the road to drive on, minimizing collisions within the country.  However, different countries may arrive at different conventions, leading to collisions between drivers from different countries.  While it would be beneficial for all countries to agree on a single convention, no individual driver can unilaterally change their behavior to achieve this, as it would increase collisions within their own country.  This highlights the challenge of achieving collective agency when individual incentives oppose it.
chunks.chunk_summary: The driving conventions problem demonstrates how individual incentives can lead to locally optimal solutions that are globally suboptimal.

chunks.text: The driving conventions problem can be formalized as a modular coordination game, where interaction strengths are higher within countries than between countries.  An energy function can be defined to represent the degree to which constraints are satisfied, with lower energy corresponding to fewer collisions.  The system tends towards local minima of this energy function, representing Nash equilibria where no individual driver can improve their outcome by unilaterally changing their behavior.  The challenge is to find a way for the system to escape these local optima and reach a global optimum where all collisions are avoided.
chunks.chunk_summary: The driving conventions problem can be formalized using an energy function, with local minima representing Nash equilibria that are difficult to escape.

chunks.text: One way to achieve a transition in agency is to change the system's behavior from following individual gradients to following a global gradient.  This requires coordinated collective action to overcome the pull of individual incentives.  While changes to interaction structures could potentially achieve this, it's difficult to explain how such changes could arise bottom-up, driven by individual incentives, when they oppose short-term individual benefits.  This is the "hard problem of transitions in agency."
chunks.chunk_summary: The challenge is to explain how changes that promote collective agency can arise bottom-up when they oppose short-term individual incentives.

chunks.text: The model explores units with a simple decision-making ability and a "decision cycle" that allows them to repeatedly revisit their decisions.  A Newtonian mechanics analogy, similar to Waddington's epigenetic landscape, is used.  A ball rolling downhill represents a unit making a decision, with the gradient determined by influences from other units.  The decision cycle involves periods of sensitivity to inputs and periods of acting on the environment.  The key is how the timing of these cycles interacts to produce collective agency.
chunks.chunk_summary: The model uses a Newtonian mechanics analogy to represent units with decision cycles, involving periods of sensitivity and action.

chunks.text: Simply repeating decisions asynchronously is not enough to solve the transitions problem.  The challenge is to find a systemic change that allows collectives to become agential and minimize collective stress.  One possibility is to change the interaction structure, but this raises the question of how such changes could arise bottom-up without presupposing higher-level agency.  The paper explores changes to the timing of decisions as a solution to this problem.
chunks.chunk_summary: The paper explores changes to the timing of decisions as a way to achieve transitions in agency without presupposing higher-level organization.

chunks.text: Allowing units to modify the timing of their decision cycles leads to local utility maximization through a process similar to phase synchronization of oscillators.  Units adjust their phase to increase synergy with others, synchronizing with those whose actions are compatible.  This creates a positive feedback loop where units that decide together wire together, resembling Hebbian learning.
chunks.chunk_summary: Units adjust their decision cycle timing to maximize synergy, leading to phase synchronization and a form of Hebbian learning.

chunks.text: The interplay between decisions (s values) and their timing (θ values) is crucial.  When units synchronize their activity, they also synchronize their inactivity, the moments when they are sensitive to external influences.  Asynchronous action leads to mutual attention within the group, preventing changes in collective decisions.  Synchronization breaks this mutual attention, allowing the group to respond to external influences and change its collective decision.
chunks.chunk_summary: Synchronization of decision cycles shifts attention from within the group to external influences, enabling changes in collective decisions.

chunks.text: An evolutionary version of the model uses adaptive dynamics to explore whether natural selection can achieve similar dynamics.  Populations of individuals with heritable θ values interact in the coordination game.  Individual fitness is determined by the utility based on their phenotype and the average phenotypes of other populations.  Mutations in θ are subject to strong selection and weak mutation assumptions.  The model demonstrates how selection can lead to the evolution of synchronized decision cycles, promoting collective agency.
chunks.chunk_summary: An evolutionary model using adaptive dynamics shows that natural selection can lead to the evolution of synchronized decision cycles and collective agency.
